metadata.Title: CVE-2019-6111 on Ubuntu 18.04 FIPS Certified (bionic) - low
metadata.Description:
An issue was discovered in OpenSSH 7.9. Due to the scp implementation beingderived from 1983 rcp, the server chooses which files/directories are sentto the client. However, the scp client only performs cursory validation ofthe object name returned (only directory traversal attacks are prevented).A malicious scp server (or Man-in-The-Middle attacker) can overwritearbitrary files in the scp client target directory. If recursive operation(-r) is performed, the server can manipulate subdirectories as well (forexample, to overwrite the .ssh/authorized_keys file).

    Update Instructions:

    Run `sudo pro fix CVE-2019-6111` to fix the vulnerability. The problem can be corrected
    by updating your system to the following package versions:

openssh-client - 1:7.9p1-6
openssh-client-hmac - 1:7.9p1-6
openssh-server - 1:7.9p1-6
openssh-server-hmac - 1:7.9p1-6
openssh-sftp-server - 1:7.9p1-6
openssh-tests - 1:7.9p1-6
ssh - 1:7.9p1-6
ssh-askpass-gnome - 1:7.9p1-6
Available with Ubuntu Pro: https://ubuntu.com/pro

criterions.comment: openssh package in fips/bionic, is related to the CVE in some way and has been fixed (note: '1:7.9p1-6').
openssh-ssh1: while related to the CVE in some way, a decision has been made to ignore this issue (note: 'end of standard support, was needs-triage').
